Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial on Robotic Surgical Skill Assessment Methods

Trial_Design.evidence: This randomised controlled trial evaluated new assessment methods for RAMIS using the da Vinci platform.

Participants.evidence: Participants were surgical trainees at a tertiary hospital, eligible if they had completed basic surgical training.

Intervention.evidence: The intervention group received automated evaluation systems, while the control group used structured grading rubrics.

Objective.evidence: This randomised controlled trial evaluated new assessment methods for RAMIS using the da Vinci platform.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the accuracy of skill assessment over a 6-month period.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was computer-generated, with allocation concealment via sealed envelopes.

Blinding.evidence: Blinding was applied to outcome assessors.

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 200 participants were randomised: 100 to the intervention and 100 to the control group, between January 2020 and June 2021.

Number_Analysed.evidence: Analysis included 98 in the intervention group and 97 in the control group using an intention-to-treat approach.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The intervention group showed improved assessment accuracy (mean difference = 5.2, 95% CI 3.1 to 7.3; p = 0.01).

Harms.evidence: No adverse events were reported, with 3% in the intervention group and 1% in the control group experiencing mild gastrointestinal side-effects.

Funding.evidence: This trial was funded by the National Institute of Health.
